reviewText:
Do you want a fighting game where you can screw around with your drunk friends on the weekends laughing at how dumb you guys look trying to fight each other, a la Sumotori Dreams? Then download this game.

Do you want a fighting simulator that you can get into immediately? Do you expect to look like the guys in that video up there right away? If you do, then don't download this game.

You'll get discouraged VERY quickly.

When they say you have total control, they mean it. You control every single muscle in your fighter's body. Are you expecting to know how to do a jump kick right away? Throw a punch? Expect to educate yourself on muscle movements instead, because trust me, you have no idea how complex even throwing a simple punch is.

I'm not kidding about learning muscle movements. You basically have to take an anatomy and physiology course before you can make your fighter even look human.

Go through the tutorial. It'll teach you some basics, but expect your fighter to look like a robot while fighting, and expect to get beat. A lot.

Then, watch some more advanced tutorials on Youtube. There are a surprising number of these, but for a game as complex as this, I'm not really that shocked. Even after practicing and watching Youtube videos, you'll still get beat, but don't get discouraged. There is a very high learning curve, but this is part of what makes this game exciting! I've played this game on and off for 7 years, and I'm still nowhere near as good as the higher ranked guys.

Playing this game takes commitment. It'll take a LONG time before your character will even make fluid movements. Don't expect to look like the guys in that video up there without years of practice. It'll take a long time, but is it worth it? You bet.

P.S. If you want to get serious and actually make your fighter look cool, be willing to spend a fortune because the shop is stupidly overpriced.

Brief Review

Toribash is a turn-based game 3D third-person tactical martial art using physics-based attacks. The game is played by relaxing, holding, extending, or contracting  the various joints on the player's character and hitting the spacebar to advance time by a user-specified amount. When properly manipulated, one ragdoll will strike the other, and if enough damage is inflicted with a single blow, a limb or body part may be dismembered, or fractured. Through careful manipulation of the ragdoll's joints, complex attacks can be performed.

TLDR; At the bottom!Due to the fact that I've played this for 600+ hours without realizing it, I thought it was time to review this game.
Toribash is a physics based fighting game. All the negative reviews you see are from people who don't have very long attention spans.
This game has a high learning curve. By high I mean it's *very* hard to get good at it unless you spend a lot of time into this game.  You need to play at least 100 - 200~ hours to get a basic understanding of the joints and how they interact with each other to make moves.
If you want to start doing the stuff that you saw in the video (they're called madmans, by the way) right away, let me tell you this.
You can't.
Yep. I've played this game for 600+ hours and I've only gotten 1 madman. And it's not even that good!
But most players don't realize that there is a forum for this game. The forums is where the actual community lies.
I've got many of my friends to download and play this game (I had to nag them so much) but they just didn't find it interesting.
Most players only play it for the lols. And that's not a bad thing.
The bad thing is that players expect this game to be easy. And when they are surprised by how hard it is to even make your character do a punch, they just quit.
Now let me state the pros and cons of this game.

Pros:A lot of replayability.
Entertaining, funny at some moments.
Has multiplayer, so, you can practically play it forever until the community or the game dies out.
Doesn't require a high end PC to run it
It's free to play.
A darn lot of gamemodes to choose from.

Cons:High learning curve.
The graphics are bad.
Requires a lot of dedication and hard work to make a good replay.
Frustrating.

Neutral:
Small, but tightly knit community.

So that's my review for Waste your life and time with ragdolls simulator.

TLDR
Don't play if you have a short attention and are serious to get good at it.
Play it if you are willing to play for fun.
Play it if you are willing to dedicate your time to get good at it.
All in all, 7.5/10 for this game.

GAMEPLAY : 10/10

Toribash is a fighthing game mix in with some simulation controls and it execute extremely well.

As you starts off the game,you are present to a tutorial on how each parts of the body work.

You can extend,relax & contract for each part of the body and it will do certain moves depending on the body part you wish to moves.

You can perform all types of moves like summersault,hipflip,uppercut,a kick to the knee,body,head and many well-made moves you can create.

First time player would have hard time learning the gameplay mechanic since Toribash were introduced to have a very complex fighthing mechanic which we never seen in any fighthing game before.

The game provide a in-game shop where you can buy bunch of effects,skins & colour. All these can bought by using the in-game currency which you can earn by winning numerous matches in online matches.

Let explain the online matches . You can set different type of rules. Players are given at least 15-30 seconds to acts depending on the timer sets. After that,an action will perform and it will last 15-30 seconds too ( it counts very fast ) and it will pause for you to acts in your next step.

GRAPHICS : 7/10

You can change too many different type of background through the settings and it a great addition if you don't like plain white background.

The characters is made by a bunch of balls ( mainly because it easier to tell which part of the body ).

The decapitation and gore is a nice touch as well as the blood texture.

AUDIO : 7/10

As you play through a lot of matches,random soundtrack will play it. Though some may find the soundtrack a bit weird ( since the music is a bit random ),it actually appealing to hear.

The sound effects when you hit your opponents and the blood squemish is not bad.

Your character doesn't have voice and only will grunt & scream.

LONG-LASTING APPEAL : 10/10

You will never get bored with this game because of how well the gameplay mechanics are executed.

It even more addicting if you play it with online people where you can see what kinds of skills they can perform.

Not to mentioned,there is a bunch of mods for you to messed around as well as bots you can face against to test and improves you skills.

FINAL VERDICT : 8.5/10

Toribash shines extremely well in the gameplay mechanics.

No other fighthing game try what Toribash did and it refreshing to see something new in the fighthing genre.

There is no pay 2 win features at all.

The game require a lot of strategy and thinking too.

Give it a try though since it doesn't require much of your free space.

GRADE : B ( Great )

reviewText:
Ever wanted to be your own Bruce Lee? Wanted to pin someone to the floor with nothing but brute force? Or did you ever want to gracefully pluck your opponents' head off their shoulders before splitting apart the rest of them with one kick? Ok maybe not the last one, but if this sounds interesting you're definitely gonna love this game. Now seriously I have never loved gore fighters. Wrestling was more of an afterthought than anything else. But there is a certain thrill you get when you're able to do a backflip and kick your opponent's arms off. This game combines the freedom of ragdoll stick figures and mortal combat in a really amazing turn-based but rapid action masterpiece.

I first heard of this game about a year ago and I was interested then, but my machine at the time couldn't run it. But I got a new one and when it came out on Steam I quickly checked it out to see what would happen. The small download size was really great as I didn't want to wait long. My first experience in the tutorial made me feel almost helpless as my character seemed to have so many parts and possible actions I didn't know how I could remember all this. The fact that it was turn-based made it seem quite complex. Fast forward 1 day later and I was a Green Belt. After looking at a few moves online and trying them out, I found a couple easy to do, easy-to-remember moves which brought me success in my games.

This game is really hilarious. I mean 'drop down dead laughing' hilarious. In low belt ranks, people who don't know how to control their characters leads to one hell of a ridiculous experience which has everyone wishing for more. The wait in large lobbies can be a little tiring but most of the time I'm enjoying watching others play and I can learn from them. The wait is also great for the moments when you wanna take a bathroom break or try to memorize a new technique online.

What makes this game stand out to me are the mods that are currently avaliable for it. Right now I can't count the number of mods that are in the list and I've only tested about twenty now. From sword-fighting to pool diving to racing, this game has it all! I could not believe my eyes when I found myself in something like a drag racer that raced down the map into the oncoming wall. Needless to say I had a very good laugh.

Already my review is really long, so I'll say this last. Download the game. Play it for even a day or two. You won't regret it. And it has a very good community, perfect for taking my mind off bad experiences in League of Legends.

reviewText:
If you don't have a basic understanding of anatomy and it's relation to physics, it will take you a very long time to get good at this game.  If you've got some rudimentary understanding of both, this game will blow your mind!

This is a sandbox/ragdoll/fighting game based around the concept of manipulating your body to complete a goal, whether it be knocking your opponent to the ground or running through an obstacle course in an attempt to knab the best time.

It has a wide variety of settings to allow you to add variety to your matches.  You could change the mod and give one of the players a sword, while leaving the other barehanded.  You can edit the gravity settings to match the real world which is something I would recommend doing, as it allows you to relate your actions to those of the real world.

It has a varied community, some are idiotic, but on the most part you'll come across experienced players who are willing to help people who have less experience with the game.  That is something that I really love about this game, it really encourages experienced players to help out the ones with less experience.  It's rewarding for both parties.  The new player learns, and the experienced player sets the new player on the road to being an opponent.  Very interesting.

Take a look if you're having doubts, it's free.  Find a player who knows what they're doing and have them teach you.

reviewText: A fun game with a rather steep learning curve, Toribash is a game where the difficulty may deter people from an otherwise enjoyable physics-strategy-sandbox-fighter-thing.\nThe genre is hard to describe, incase you couldn't tell.\nIn Toribash you get your awesome Bruce Lee-esque ragdoll (called a Tori) to fight other people's ragdolls by adjusting the joints to allow it to move and perform attacks through a floaty physics engine that seems like you're fighting underwater. In theory, this could be clunky and not-fun. Toribash executes this concept really well, and while the learning curve is steep, as I said earlier, the large amount of flexibility in your moves makes up for this fact. Once you understand how the system and the different joints work, you can do practically any move with your Tori that you can imagine. Trip the opponent with one foot, then jumpkick their head off with the other foot. Grab them, toss them over your shoulder then tear their arms off with your feet. It's a lot of fun, with many different mods and gamemodes to extend it further. The only thing that is keeping this game from gaining more popularity is the learning curve, which has it on you more rough than Street Fighter 4. The game is free as well, so that means a good amount of fun for the extremely low price of $0.

reviewText:
F2P games that come with no strings attached are rare enough.

Ones that are fun and completely skill-driven even more so.

Toribash is, to me, F2P done right, and it is one of the most unique games I've ever played in my long years of gaming.

A Versus-Brawler at heart, there are no pre-defined moves or button combinations to pull off stunts - It's entirely physics driven, and you actually create your moves on-the-fly.

The learning curve is steep, but nothing is more satisfying than pulling off insane moves and crushing your opponent by ripping their head off.

The characters consist of spheres, which roughly represent human muscle centers, and can be expanded, contracted, lowered, raised, held or relaxed. Fights take place in turns, with various rules according to the room you are currently in, such as number of frames per round.

The players have a certain amount of time to allocate their limb states (see above), and the move - or part of the move - is executed simultaniously.

It's really hard to explain - Toribash is best experienced first hand.
Don't be put off by being confused, not knowing what the hell you are supposed to do - there is a fairly basic, but really essential tutorial build in, and you are free to pummel the non-responsive bot or even load in a script that makes him act a bit, all for training.

Also, don't be put off by entering the beginner rooms in the online modes - Toribash has, oddly enough for such a competetive game, one of the most laid-back and friendly communities you will ever encounter.
I can't stress this point enough - as a veteran of quite some online games, I have never, ever had so much fun with random people.

reviewText:
This isn't your average fighting game.

Toribash is about pulling off awesome moves to defeat manequin-like people, if it was that easy. It is extremely complicated and takes a while to get used to. So unless you are willing to invest a large amount of your time in this I would leave it alone.

Starting to play this game I would start clicking on random body parts trying to kick the other guy in the face and eventually fall over onto the floor and flop around trying to get back up until I get disqualified because something other than my limbs brushed the floor like I was playing 'the floor is lava'. After I got the hang of it (to a degree) I started to pull of some cool moves and I did have a bit of fun with it. Even if I still kept falling over onto the floor.

I also tried it out with my friends, which I have to say was a lot of fun. Most of the games ended up with us both on the floor swinging random body parts around in an attempt to hit eachother while trying not to get disqualified until it ended up like the least interesting game of twister ever. But in the end we had a good laugh.

There are also a lot of mods (and I mean a lot) for this game, that can change it completely and make the game a bit more interesting. I won't go too much in detail about that though as there are too many mods to write a review on.

This game is definately worth picking up especially for the fact that is free, it's definately a unique experience for the fighting genre and it equals for a good laugh with friends.

8/10 :)

Let me get right to the point and say I love this game. When I first started out about a year ago I felt like a toddler learning to walk, and I admit, it was a bit frustrating. Then I turned to Youtube. I learned a few basic aikido and judo (two different mods/game modes in the game) opening moves and from there my results sky-rocketted. I was flooring noobs left and right until I got to the intermediate level where (most) every player had a rudimentary understanding of how to move in the game then it was fairly evenly matched and I quickly got over myself.
Here's some things that are just excellent about the game:
-- IT'S FREE. TRY IT.
-- The graphics are so simplistic it could run on a computer from the 90's, but at the same time it doesn't look bad, and when you use shaders it looks quite nice. (My opinion, of course)
-- The game is utterly unique, you'll never play anything like it.
-- The game can be quite dramatic and/or comical when you watch people who actually know how to play do what they do. Think of it like the WWE, just not scripted.
-- You have nearly complete conrol of your character, which could be a bit overwhelming, but once you understand the functions of the joints you will come to enjoy it as well.
-- The community is very tightly-knit. You seldom come across a player you just can't get along with.
-- Being good in this game is not matter of higher level, better quipment or any of that junk. Being good in this game comes down to one factor. Skill.
-- There are tons of events to take part in.

Now, to be fair, here are some things that kind of suck about the game.
-- Store items are a bit expensive, and it's a bit difficult to earn money. That being said you don't have to pay real money for most of the store items, and they're really just accessories.
-- The community is small compared to other games. This is the consequence of the tightly-knit community I mentioned earlier.
-- I said earlier how skill is the deciding factor of this game, but it can also be considered a bad thing as you have to fumble around a bit to get the hang of the game, which can be frustrating if you're the impatient type like myself.

reviewText:
Been playing this for a while now, I can safely say it's one of the best multiplayer competitive free to play games out there.

Toribash's design philosophy is very simple and elegant. The game works by manipulating multiple joints on your character's body in order to execute movements under the timer of a turn. When done properly, the character's ragdoll (known in-game as a Tori) will be able to hit and/or grab an opponent. The player is awarded with points for sucessful hits on most of the many parts of an opponent's body. Usually, a game is won when an illegal part of a Tori's body touches the ground, or when any part touches down outside the designated dojo area, or when the match timer reaches zero and the points are compared.

Because of this, the game has a nigh-infinite variety of possible fight scenarios, although most players will find that fights tend to follow some kind of pattern as the various common strategies are countered time and again. Despite its variety, the game suffers from a high entrance barrier for most newcomers. First learning how to properly manipulate your Tori and composing your first moves can be very daunting and no doubt will turn some down from the experience. Fortunately, the community is ever helpful, and many guides and tutorials are available to help newcomers overcome this first major obstacle.

I very much recommend Toribash. It's a truly addicting and satisfying experience with one of the best free to play models I've ever known. The playerbase is incredibly active and frequently engages in many competitive events that award the winner with various prizes. Even if the learning process might feel somewhat frustrating, It's all worth it when you finally get into a public server ready to kick some ♥♥♥.

Toribash is a fun and unique game for everyone, I first played in 2009 and I still get the same feels from playing.

Toribash is not a typical button-mash fighting game you would see out there, you actually have control of your own character and you adjust every single little move you make.
At first when you start the game, it seems really complicated and difficult but the fight school shows you the basics of this game pretty well.

You don't need much skill at beginner levels if you go play with other people in multiplayer because there are the belts  which are basically the ranks. The more you play, the more you get experience and that means you gain belts so you can fight with people who are equally skilled with you! This is not obligatory though, you can still keep fighting the most known person in Toribash, Uke. Or you can just make your own server and play there with friends or whoever you want to without the need of thinking about rankings or belts.

You can also play hundreds of different mods which players have made to make the game more interesting and awesome, there are mods like aikido and judo but there's also mods where you can be involved in a car crash or even go skiing.

Toribash has a very nice community, it's really fun, challenging and can keep you occupied for a long time.

reviewText:
I would say this was one of the most interesting and entertaining fighting games I have ever played but it is so unlike other fighting games that there would be no point. It has taken ragdoll physics gaming to a different level by making it turnbased and allowing almost infinite controll over the ragdoll (20 limbs which can each be extended, contracted, relaxed or held still individually) each turn. Saying it is the best fighting game I have ever played would also be pointles because it is one of the only fighting games I have ever played but this is not important...

It is a hard game to get the hang of and may take a lot of time if you want to get good, but if you do not want to expend so much effort then you can have just as much fun playing the weird and wacky gamemodes on multiplayer. The selection of gamemodes spans from skiing, to icehockey and even skatebording if you think you are good enough. The variety of fighting gamemodes is just as widespread and it should not just be treated as a funny and novel simulator as many indie games (I don't really like that term) which employ new and original mechanics are. I can tell you that if you put in the hours of dedication to this game it will be worth it and you are able to achieve fame in the community if you are good enough (not that I have any sort of fame).

I have written too much and I can't expect any of you to read this far but if you have I thank you and would strongly urgh you to try this game and dive into the community and the forums where you can find other player's replays as well as downloading new player-made gamemodes if you ever get bored of the preinstalled collection which come as part of the game.

and again, thank you for reading.

reviewText:
Toribash is a fun and unique game for everyone, I first played in 2009 and I still get the same feels from playing.

Toribash is not a typical button-mash fighting game you would see out there, you actually have control of your own character and you adjust every single little move you make.
At first when you start the game, it seems really complicated and difficult but the fight school shows you the basics of this game pretty well.

You don't need much skill at beginner levels if you go play with other people in multiplayer because there are the belts  which are basically the ranks. The more you play, the more you get experience and that means you gain belts so you can fight with people who are equally skilled with you! This is not obligatory though, you can still keep fighting the most known person in Toribash, Uke. Or you can just make your own server and play there with friends or whoever you want to without the need of thinking about rankings or belts.

You can also play hundreds of different mods which players have made to make the game more interesting and awesome, there are mods like aikido and judo but there's also mods where you can be involved in a car crash or even go skiing.

Toribash has a very nice community, it's really fun, challenging and can keep you occupied for a long time.

reviewText:
Toribash is a fun and unique game for everyone, I first played in 2009 and I still get the same feels from playing.

Toribash is not a typical button-mash fighting game you would see out there, you actually have control of your own character and you adjust every single little move you make.
At first when you start the game, it seems really complicated and difficult but the fight school shows you the basics of this game pretty well.

You don't need much skill at beginner levels if you go play with other people in multiplayer because there are the belts  which are basically the ranks. The more you play, the more you get experience and that means you gain belts so you can fight with people who are equally skilled with you! This is not obligatory though, you can still keep fighting the most known person in Toribash, Uke. Or you can just make your own server and play there with friends or whoever you want to without the need of thinking about rankings or belts.

You can also play hundreds of different mods which players have made to make the game more interesting and awesome, there are mods like aikido and judo but there's also mods where you can be involved in a car crash or even go skiing.

Toribash has a very nice community, it's really fun, challenging and can keep you occupied for a long time.

2 People didnt find my Review helpful, so here will come a (hopefully) helpful review :)

Toribash is hard to describe, because there is no other game similiar to it.

there are many, many, many different mods like jumping, penalty kicks (soccer), dunking (basketball) but the main part lies in 1vs1 fighting mods like aikido, wushu and so on.

Its basicly turn based. a round has an amount of frames (which differs from mod to mod) which are executed in steps. both players click theri  joints and hit ready to see both fighters do the moves and stop again to change for the next framestep.

after each game u see the fight as a whole (and ofc u can save and even edit (!) the replays) so its a very visual game, 30% for me is watching awsome replays

the only problem about the game is, that it is so hard to begin with! in the start i cudnt do anything. no hit, no kick, basicly i was just falling down.
but if u get a little understanding of it its a really cool and unique game.

and you should know that you will probably never be able to move like in the trailers :) thats so super hard..
